Award.AwardTitle: 2013 Frontiers of Engineering Symposia (German-American, China-America, US, and EU-US)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award partially supports a series of four national and international Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) Symposia, to be held in 2013, organized by the National Academy of Engineering for early career researchers: German-American FOE (April 26-28 in Irvine, California), China-America FOE (May 15-17 in Beijing, China), U.S. FOE (September 19-21 in Wilmington, Delaware), and European Union-U.S. FOE (November 21-23 in Chantilly, France). Each symposium focuses on four topical areas. The topics for the 2013 symposia are the following: social media, flexible electronics, renewable energy, smart manufacturing, biomass conversion, materiomics, transport in complex systems, additive manufacturing, nanomaterials, solar energy, bio-MEMS, future of the Internet, nanosensors, big data, future of transportation, and wireless broadband. About 100 outstanding young engineers for the U.S. symposium and 30 from each country for the bilateral symposia will participate. Each two and one-half day symposium includes four formal sessions, technical tours, break-out sessions, and opportunities for developing collaborative research partnerships. Sessions consist of presentations on cutting-edge research, innovations, and emerging research opportunities in engineering fields relevant to the symposium.

The FOE symposia provide early career scientists and engineers the opportunity for sharing research insights and techniques to foster new collaborations and, in the case of the bilateral meetings, deepen technical and cultural understanding between the countries' participants. The symposia foster interdisciplinary and international collaborations and serve as a reference point for many of the emerging frontiers in research and innovation in the United States. American innovative capacity is strengthened through these exchanges. Papers from the U.S. FOE symposium will be published in a volume available on the National Academies Press website at http://www.nap.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Frontiers of Engineering (FOE) program brings together a select group of engineers (ages 30-45) from industry, academia, and government labs for 2.5-day meetings to discuss pioneering technical work and leading-edge research in various engineering fields and industry sectors. The goal is to facilitate an interdisciplinary exchange of knowledge and methodology that could lead to collaborative networks of engineers. NSF provided partial funding for four FOE symposia in 2013: US Frontiers of Engineering (USFOE) held September 19-21 in Wilmington, Delaware; German-American Frontiers of Engineering (GAFOE) held April 26-28 in Irvine, California; China-America Frontiers of Engineering (CAFOE) held May 15-17 in Beijing, China; and EU-US Frontiers of Engineering (EU-US FOE) held November 21-23 in Chantilly, France. Almost 280 engineers attended the symposia where selected topics such as biocompatible materials for optoelectronic neural probes, modeling large-scale networks, design for additive manufacturing, fabrication and application of nanoparticles, impacts of the sharing economy in transportation, and production and utilization of green hydrogen, among others, were covered. Symposium materials can be found at www.naefrontiers.org.

Outcomes described in evaluation forms:

USFOE
Rated good or excellent:
Meeting format 97%
Choice of topics  85%
Quality of presentations  91%
Level of engineering covered  83%
Your opportunity to participate  94%

"I am intrigued as to why I liked so much the first session on social networks despite the lack of connection with my current work. Was it that the speakers were very engaging? Was it that the topic was of interest to me, and I didn't know? Was it that I think this topic should be of interest to everyone? I guess what is most attractive is that we don't know how to use these data yet, and it is puzzling. I like puzzles."

"I am a huge fan of cross-pollination, and as my field is rather specialized, I really appreciated the chance to mingle with top-notch researchers in other fields."

"The presentations were high-quality and accessible to non-experts. They helped broaden my interests and become more curious about other people's disciplines."

GAFOE
Rated good or excellent:
Meeting format  97%
Choice of topics  94%
Quality of presentations  97%
Level of engineering covered  89%
Your opportunity to participate  94%

"I categorize this symposium as a 'growth' activity. I have shared what I learned with several colleagues and it has enriched our discussions. Specifically I connected with several people regarding collaborative work on hydrogels and freeform fabricated scaffolds. I am forwarding papers of two German attendees to people I work with who are working in the same areas."

"You often get narrow-minded in your own discipline. I was able to identify more fundamental scientific and engineering truths by seeing other disciplines' findings."

CAFOE
Meeting format  97%
Choice of topics  94%
Quality of presentations  97%
Level of engineering covered  89%
Your opportunity to participate  94%

"I have plans to visit two universities and one company to give a talk on research in my group. I have contacts now in advanced network technologies for a potential collaboration of relevance to commercial aircraft. I have learned about possible application of novel plexiglass technologies to our microlattice materials."

"I hear again and again from previous FOE attendees that they really appreciate the breadth of the symposia. The nature of the meeting enables you to learn from leading researchers about a new fi...

NSF provided partial funding for four FOE symposia in 2013: US Frontiers of Engineering (USFOE) held September 19-21 in Wilmington, Delaware; German-American Frontiers of Engineering (GAFOE) held April 26-28 in Irvine, California; China-America Frontiers of Engineering (CAFOE) held May 15-17 in Beijing, China; and EU-US Frontiers of Engineering (EU-US FOE) held November 21-23 in Chantilly, France. The nature of the meeting enables you to learn from leading researchers about a new field in a 'guilt-free' setting. I cannot think of a better way to broaden your understanding of new engineering ideas."
